explanation:
For checking unreachable code in OS_TaskGetInfo you must know which control-flow paths can actually execute and which calls/macros may abort/return early or always fail/succeed:

- OS_CHECK_POINTER: macro invoked at the top; it may return, longjmp, abort, or otherwise stop execution when task_prop is bad. If it aborts/returns the rest is unreachable for certain inputs.
- OS_ObjectIdGetById: the if-block is guarded by its return value; you must inspect its implementation/specification to know whether it can return OS_SUCCESS for any inputs (i.e., whether the if branch is reachable) and whether it has side effects (e.g., never returns).
- OS_SUCCESS: the constant compared to return_code; needed to interpret OS_ObjectIdGetById results and decide reachability of the if branch.
- OS_object_token_t: the token type returned by OS_ObjectIdGetById and passed to subsequent macros; its semantics (e.g., valid/invalid token values) affect whether subsequent table lookups are meaningful or skipped.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: macro that maps a token to record/task pointers; its behavior may return NULL, assert, or otherwise alter control flow — necessary to know whether dereferences that follow are reachable or protected.
- OS_global_task_table and OS_task_table: the globals passed to OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET; their presence/contents and how the macro uses them determine if record/task pointers can be obtained (affecting reachability of name/field accesses).
- OS_common_record_t: structure type for record; you need its fields (name_entry, creator) and possible invariants (e.g., name_entry always non-NULL) to decide reachability of the name copy and creator assignment.
- OS_task_internal_record_t: structure type for task; its fields (stack_size, priority) and invariants affect reachability/validity of those assignments.
- OS_task_prop_t: target structure (size of name field, etc.); needed because the code zeroes and writes into it — if its definition or size makes those operations invalid or if its pointer handling interacts with OS_CHECK_POINTER, that impacts reachability/validity.
- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE and OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL: constants passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById that may alter its behavior (e.g., cause it to always fail or always succeed) — relevant to whether the if branch can be entered.
- OS_TaskGetInfo_Impl: called inside the if; it may not return (could abort/longjmp) or may influence later control flow, so its behavior matters for reachability of code after its call.
- OS_ObjectIdRelease: called at the end of the if block; if it can abort/longjmp, that affects reachability of code after the release or even whether the release call itself is reachable.

Together these symbols let an analyst determine whether the conditional and subsequent branches in OS_TaskGetInfo can ever be reached or are effectively unreachable for all inputs, and whether any macros/functions inside can cause early termination that renders code unreachable.
